ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to read dense philosophical essays and interpret information from it. I also improved my argumentative writing skills.

This class probably changed the way I think more than any other class I have taken here. We read mostly late 20th century political philosophy, covering human reason, violence, truth, progress, and related subjects.

I developed greater skill in close reading difficult analytical texts, and drawing broader conclusions from them. I also learned to take greater care in delineating my terms in discussion and writing.
I learned about the various conceptions and roles of violence and nonviolence. Super interesting!
Advanced political theory class. Developed skills in analytical plus continental philosophy, synthesizing a really diverse range of texts,
Learned about how to define and dissect the different forms of violence. Apart from the political philosophy we read, I learned how to critically evaluate situations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A big strength of the class was the wide array of literature that was read. Gave a wide variety of perspective. Professor Kapustin is also a great professor who facilitates discussion well and expands on the readings.

The course is truly insightful, mostly because the professor has a wealth of knowledge. The readings are hard--among the hardest of any I've done at Yale, but each seminar is a real learning opportunity. I think the class would be better restricted to people with a little more philosophical background. It is hard to jump into such complex discussions without some familiarity with process of philosophical argumentation and discussion. Though the class was rather large, the people who participated were mostly upper-level students. Also, the feedback on the essays is among the best I have received, really pushing me to think more about what I wrote.

The course is strong in its syllabus, which is fascinating and prompts a high level of engagement. Our discussions were great. Sometimes, though, the reading was simply too much to get all of it done.
Very interesting readings and engaging professor

Strengths: Prof Kapustin is amazing and directing discussions. His passion for the subject makes me care more. 

Weaknesses: NA

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Great in depth discussion of violence in political spheres.

I would absolutely recommend it. This class changed the way I think about people, political struggle, morality, and the possibility of human development/progress. It is deeply philosophical, and the readings are very challenging, but it is also incredibly rewarding.
I absolutely would. Professor Kapustin is brilliant, and it was such a serious class in a really productive way.
Yes. Kapustin leads seminars super well, and is great at guiding the class towards the main concepts. Intellectually stimulating, and I learned a lot

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in political theory (especially twentieth-century political theory) and connecting it to modern instances of revolution and political violence. Professor Kapustin is a wonderful seminar leader and also a great teacher in one-on-one advising.
Yes, I never thought I'd be interested in violence but found that this topic is extremely fundamental to how our society organizes, maintains power, and bleeds into the daily functions of our lives.
